A sticky broadcast lives for the life of the phone, but for what functions? Android apps and the Android system can use broadcasts as a messaging system to notify other apps of events that they might be interested in. Sticky broadcasts are a special type of broadcast for which the sent intent object(s) remains in the cache after the broadcast is complete. The system may re-broadcast sticky intents to later registrations of receivers
(ref:https://developer.android.com/topic/security/risks/sticky-broadcast)
For example, a music player app might send a sticky broadcast when the current song changes, allowing other apps or widgets to update their information accordingly. - But not for video / streaming. VpnService is a base class for applications to extend and build their own VPN solutions. In general, it creates a virtual network interface, configures addresses and routing rules, and returns a file descriptor to the application. Each read from the descriptor retrieves an outgoing packet which was routed to the interface. Each write to the descriptor injects an incoming packet just like it was received from the interface
Services extending this class need to be declared with an appropriate permission and intent filter. Their access must be secured by Manifest.permission.BIND_VPN_SERVICE permission, and their intent filter must match SERVICE_INTERFACE action. Here is an example of declaring a VPN service in AndroidManifest.xml:
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/net/VpnService
To add a VPN service to your app, create an Android service inheriting from VpnService. Declare the VPN service in your app manifest file with the following additions:
Protect the service with the BIND_VPN_SERVICE permission so that only the system can bind to your service.
Advertise the service with the "android.net.VpnService" intent filter so that the system can find your service.

Apps that require the android.permission.ACCESS_SURFACE_FLINGER permission typically fall into the following categories:

1. Screen Recording Apps: Apps that record the device's screen, such as screencasting or game recording apps, require this permission to access the SurfaceFlinger service, which manages the composition and display of graphics on the screen. This permission allows these apps to capture the visual content being displayed on the screen and record it as a video.

2. Live Wallpaper Apps: Live wallpapers are animated or interactive wallpapers that run on the device's home screen. To function properly, live wallpaper apps need access to the SurfaceFlinger service to render and display their animations or interactive elements on the screen.

3. Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) Apps: VR and AR apps often require low-latency access to the display to provide immersive experiences. The android.permission.ACCESS_SURFACE_FLINGER permission allows these apps to bypass the normal graphics pipeline and directly interact with the SurfaceFlinger service, reducing latency and improving the overall VR/AR experience.

4. Screen Mirroring Apps: Apps that enable screen mirroring or casting to external displays, such as TVs or projectors, require this permission to access the SurfaceFlinger service and capture the device's screen content for mirroring purposes.

ASEC (Android Secure External Cache) - implemented in a time when Android devices come with limited storage and has to resort to external storage (i.e. SD card) for apps, and its purpose is to securely store part of the apps so as to prevent corruption and piracy by copying SD card contents.
From Wikipedia: Applications moved to an SD card use an ASEC extension. These files can then be found under the .android_secure folder on the SD card. If an application must be moved from memory back to its device’s local storage, the file is decrypted from the ASEC file format to a basic APK (Android Package) file format.
To achieve "Move to SD card" feature.
Also used in Android 4.1 as "Forward Locking" (to protect paid apps not to be copied and shared)
However, ASEC container management (creating, deleting, mounting, and unmounting) is (should be) implemented in the system volume daemon (vold)

Bind to a service - means creating a connection between your application and a service that is running in the background. This allows your application to interact with the service and access its functionality. 
Once you have bound to a service, you can call its methods and access its fields. You can also receive callbacks from the service when its state changes.
Binding to a service is a powerful way to interact with background services in Android. However, it is important to note that binding to a service can be expensive in terms of performance. Therefore, you should only bind to a service when you need to access its functionality. (Google-PaLM)

When a client binds to a service, it creates a long-term association with the service, enabling ongoing interaction. This is typically done by calling the bindService() method, passing an Intent to specify the service to bind to. (ChatGPT)
